Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Cybersecurity with Undergraduate IT Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cybersecurity has become a matter of national and global importance because of the economy's dependence on the Internet, and on cyber-infrastructure. Workforce development through cyber education and training are key towards protecting the ever-growing cyberspace and cyberinfrastructure. However, US universities are not graduating nearly sufficient workforce in the IT areas, let alone cybersecurity. Academic programs in STEM and IT fields are uniquely positioned to address this need. Tailoring curricula in these areas to include cyber education can bridge the gap existing between the demand and supply of trained workforce. Existing certificate programs do not offer a data analytics perspective along with a software security and network security perspective for undergraduate curricula. In addition, the existing certificates are not seamlessly integrated with the existing curriculum towards a bachelor?s degree. This project is motivated to fill this gap.

The key objective of this project is to increase the capacity in the cybersecurity workforce by creating, delivering and assessing a new undergraduate certificate program in cybersecurity. This will include developing a model curriculum and material for undergraduate cyber education grounded on the pedagogical literature. In addition, this project will design and develop intervention strategies using peer mentoring between advanced cybersecurity courses and an entry level Information Systems course. This will provide a framework for learning and retention through peer mentoring, early intervention strategies, group engagement, critical thinking through capstone projects, and individualized learning of deeper issues in cybersecurity through one-on-one interactions with faculty. A certificate program will be designed to increase interest in cyber education as well as increase retention and completion of the program by undergraduate students. The project will also include qualitative and quantitative evaluations of the effectiveness of the certificate program. The certificate program will (a) Develop skills in technical, analytical, software security, and critical thinking, (b) Allow students to apply the knowledge gained to projects that simulate real-life problems, (c) Nurture and support innovative thinking in solving some of the key challenges facing the cyber world, (d) Expose students to various career opportunities in the cyber industry and connect them with relevant professional groups, and (e) Increase the cybersecurity workforce capacity to support this pervasive area with a growing importance in society. The certificate program will result in products and outcomes that can be used as a model for adoption in other undergraduate curricula in computing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project resulted in a successful undergraduate certificate program on Cybersecurity Informatics that is open to all undergraduate students at the University. The certificate was approved by the university administration and has been in operation for a few years with the first cohort of students graduating in 2018. So far the program has graduated ten students, many of whom are currently working as cybersecurity professionals while others are pursuing graduate programs in related fields. Currently there are thirty seven students in the certificate program with a growing trend in enrollment. The certificate program and the two new courses on cybersecurity analytics and software security along with the other courses in the program will continue to be offered in the Information Systems at UMBC. The peer mentoring approach shows a helpful trend in encouraging lower division undergraduate students to pursue studies and careers in cybersecurity. From the student feedback we have received bridging cybersecurity with analytics fills an important void in our undergraduate IT related programs. Majors from other programs including Math/Stats, Computer Engineering, and Computer Science have shown interest in this area. The project results have been disseminated via research papers that are presented at various workshops, and published in conference proceedings.  The project has resulted in a successful certificate program in cybersecurity informatics that will be sustained well beyond the years that the project has been funded. The peer mentoring approach has resulted in encouraging upper division undergraduate students to interact with their junior counterparts and the lower division undergraduate students in getting valuable perspectives in this area. The project demonstrates both the need as well as the feasibility of integrating cybersecurity education in existing undergraduate IT programs. We have demonstrated that such prograns are both sustainable and valuable for educating and developing workforce in this critical area.
